coredata.dc:title: Cooperative effects on the single-particle dynamics in simple liquids
coredata.dc:creator: Balucani, U.
Gori, M.
Vallauri, R.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The collective motion of clusters of particles has been studied by computer simulation for a Lennard-Jones system close to its triple point. The single-particle displacement is analyzed with respect to the collective character of the dynamics of these clusters.

Introduction Since the advent of computer simulation for the study of the dynamical properties of liquids, a great deal of detailed information has been gained on the physical processes underlying the transport mecha- nisms. In particular the diffusion of a single particle has been the subject of numerous investigations and different interpretations have been proposed [1] . The linear time dependence of the mean-square dis- placement of a tagged particle suggests naturally a Brownian-like motion, despite the size and mass of the diffusive particle. However, this simple descrip- tion is found to be insufficient for the interpretation of the corresponding single-particle velocity correla- tion function, for which the memory effects are of overwhelming relevance. From the point of view of the diffusion, this would imply the existence of defi- nite correlations between the motion of different particles. Recent computer simulations [2] on Lennard-Jones liquids have shown, on a quantitative basis, such effects. Such a con- cept has recently been stressed by Stulinger and Weber [4] by the so called quenching method. Starting from a general equilibrium configuration of atoms in the liquid phase, they look for the position of the particles for which a minimum of the potential energy of the whole system is achieved. The pair distribution func- tion of such configurations is found to be close to the pair distribution of an amorphous solid as evaluated by Rahman et al- [5] , and independent of the temper- ature of the starting thermodynamic state of the sys- tem. Such "experimental" evidence for hidden struc- tures supports the calculation of the pair distribution function, G(r), performed by some authors [6]. Conclusions In conclusion we have shown that a collective de- scription of the single particle in liquids, is possible at a microscopic level. The cooperative motion of a clus- ter of particles has been revealed by following the dis- placement of-the-center of mass of the cluster. Two main features have been pointed out and measured by computer simulation: (i) the existence of cooperative displacements of particles belonging to a cluster, which can extend as far as a second shell of neighbours, (ii) the collective rotation of the cluster. It has also been shown that the "behaviour of the normalized center-of- mass velocity correlation function is closer to that of a massive particle- which goes to zero without becom- ing negative, thereby suggesting tlie picture of a Brownian dynamics, deserving a more extensive inves- tigation.
